extracted_ttps.description: The attacker used a scheduled task to execute a .BAT file, which in turn executed a cmd.exe command with arguments to configure and activate the HrServ web shell
The attacker used a custom DLL file (hrserv.dll) to hijack the execution flow of a legitimate system process
The attacker created a scheduled task named MicrosoftsUpdate to execute a .BAT file, which configured and activated the HrServ web shell as a system service
The implant uses cmd to execute commands and delete files
The implant deletes scheduled tasks and files to erase traces
The implant uses the registry as a communication channel
The web shell URL is accessed, potentially by a user
The implant retrieves information from the registry
Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Command and Scripting Interpreter activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Obfuscated Files or Information activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Scheduled Task/Job activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Registry Run Keys activity via NLP pattern matching
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Command and Scripting Interpreter
rules.description: The attacker used a scheduled task to execute a .BAT file, which in turn executed a cmd.exe command with arguments to configure and activate the HrServ web shell

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Hijack Execution Flow via Custom DLL
rules.description: Detects the use of a custom DLL file (hrserv.dll) to hijack the execution flow of a legitimate system process
falsepositives: Legitimate use of the hrserv.dll file by a system process

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process via Scheduled Task
rules.description: Detects the creation or modification of a system process through a scheduled task, potentially indicating persistence tactics by an adversary
falsepositives: Software installation or updates that use scheduled tasks

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Indicator Removal on Host (Defense Evasion)
rules.description: Detects the deletion of scheduled tasks and files to erase traces of malicious activity

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detection: Modify Registry
rules.description: The implant uses the registry as a communication channel

rules.title: Detection of User Execution via MSExchangeService.svc Access
rules.description: Identifies potential user execution of malicious code through access to the MSExchangeService.svc URL, which may indicate a web shell
falsepositives: Legitimate access to MSExchangeService.svc by system administrators or users
False positives may occur due to misconfigured or malformed URLs

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

attacks.description: Basic execution of a .BAT file using cmd.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The test.bat file will be executed, and its contents will be run in the command prompt.

attacks.description: Intermediate execution of a .BAT file using a scheduled task
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'Test Task' will be created, which will execute the test.bat file daily.

attacks.description: Advanced execution of an encoded command using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A test.bat file will be created with the contents 'echo Hello World', and then it will be executed using cmd.exe.

attacks.description: Basic: User cron job executing a benign script that writes a test file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/test.sh and schedules it to run every minute, writing 'hrserv_test' to /tmp/testfile

attacks.description: Intermediate: System-level cron job requiring root to write to log file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates privileged cron job in /etc/cron.daily that appends test string to system logs

attacks.description: Advanced: Inline bash command with output redirection via cron
attacks.expected_behavior: Schedules inline bash command to write 'hrserv_advanced_test' to /tmp/adv_test.log every minute

attacks.description: Register the custom DLL file using regsvr32
attacks.expected_behavior: The custom DLL file will be registered and can potentially hijack the execution flow of a legitimate system process

attacks.description: Check for admin privileges using whoami
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display the current user's privileges

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -TypeDefinition 'using System; public class HRServ { public static void Main() { Console.WriteLine("Hijack Execution Flow"); } }' -OutputAssembly %TEMP%\hrserv.dll; Start-Process regsvr32 -ArgumentList '/s', '%TEMP%\hrserv.dll'"
attacks.description: Create a custom DLL file using PowerShell and register it using regsvr32
attacks.expected_behavior: The custom DLL file will be created and registered, and can potentially hijack the execution flow of a legitimate system process

attacks.description: Uses LD_PRELOAD to load a benign shared library before executing a system binary
attacks.expected_behavior: The system binary (uptime) loads the specified .so from /tmp during execution

attacks.description: Persistent library hijack by adding custom path to ld config and replacing critical library (requires root)
attacks.expected_behavior: System-wide processes load the benign library from /tmp/malicious_lib due to modified ld configuration

attacks.description: Create a daily scheduled task named TestUpdate to execute a command that writes a test string to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task is created, and upon execution, it writes a test string to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.command: sc.exe create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo TestService > %TEMP%\testservice.txt"
attacks.description: Create a system service named TestService that executes a command to write a test string to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A system service is created, and upon start, it writes a test string to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Using PowerShell, create a new process that runs as an administrator and executes a command to write an advanced test string to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new process is created with elevated privileges, and it writes an advanced test string to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.command: sudo crontab -e && echo '* * * * * /bin/bash -c "echo Hello > /tmp/test.txt"' >> /tmp/crontab.txt && sudo crontab /tmp/crontab.txt
attacks.description: Basic: Modify the system cron table to execute a command every minute, writing 'Hello' to /tmp/test.txt. Requires admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will append a line to the cron table, scheduling the execution of the echo command every minute, resulting in the periodic creation or modification of /tmp/test.txt.

attacks.command:
sudo systemctl start httpd && sudo echo '[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/bash -c "echo Hello > /tmp/test.txt"
' > /etc/systemd/system/myservice.service && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl start myservice
attacks.description: Intermediate: Create a new systemd service that executes a command, writing 'Hello' to /tmp/test.txt. Requires admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a new systemd service, reload the daemon, and start the service, resulting in the execution of the echo command and the creation or modification of /tmp/test.txt.

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'echo "* * * * * /bin/bash -c \"echo Hello > /tmp/test.txt\"" | crontab -' && sudo systemctl start httpd && sudo bash -c 'echo "[Service]\nExecStart=/bin/bash -c \"echo Hello > /tmp/test2.txt\"\n" > /etc/systemd/system/myservice2.service' && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl start myservice2
attacks.description: Advanced: Combine cron and systemd to execute two different commands, writing 'Hello' to /tmp/test.txt and /tmp/test2.txt. Requires admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will schedule a cron job and create a new systemd service, both executing echo commands that create or modify /tmp/test.txt and /tmp/test2.txt, respectively.

attacks.description: Delete a scheduled task named "Test Task"
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task "Test Task" will be deleted.

attacks.description: Delete a file named "testfile.txt" in the temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: The file "testfile.txt" in the temporary directory will be deleted.

attacks.description: Delete a file named "testfile.txt" in the temporary directory using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The file "testfile.txt" in the temporary directory will be deleted.

attacks.description: Remove all cron jobs for current user
attacks.expected_behavior: Deletes all cron entries for the current user's crontab file. Leaves system cron directories (/etc/cron*) untouched.

attacks.description: Delete system-level cron job file
attacks.expected_behavior: Forcibly removes a cron job file from /etc/cron.d directory. Requires root privileges to modify system cron files.

attacks.command: sudo systemctl disable --now test-service && sudo shred -u /var/log/test-service.log
attacks.description: Disable systemd service and securely delete logs
attacks.expected_behavior: Disables and stops a systemd service, then securely deletes associated log file using shred to prevent recovery.

attacks.description: Create a new registry key in the Run folder to simulate persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: A new registry key is created in the Run folder

attacks.description: Modify an existing registry key in the Run folder
attacks.expected_behavior: The existing registry key is modified in the Run folder

attacks.description: Delete a registry key in the Run folder
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key is deleted from the Run folder

attacks.description: Sets a test value in GNOME registry-like configuration
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes 'test-value' to user-level GNOME configuration database, simulating registry modification

attacks.description: Appends test entry to system-wide environment variables
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds persistent system-wide environment variable acting as registry entry

attacks.description: Basic download of web shell file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads test.txt from example.com to TEMP directory using certificate utility

attacks.description: Intermediate download using PowerShell web request
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads test.txt via PowerShell to TEMP directory without execution

attacks.description: Advanced scriptlet execution from URL via regsvr32
attacks.expected_behavior: Executes remote scriptlet (test.sct) from example.com without persistence

attacks.description: Access a potentially malicious script from a URL and execute it using bash.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a script from the specified URL and executes it, potentially leading to the execution of malicious code.

attacks.description: Download a potentially malicious file, make it executable, and then execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file, changes its permissions to make it executable, and then runs it, which could lead to malicious activity.

attacks.description: Use Python to execute a system command that writes to a file, simulating potential malicious activity.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uses Python to execute a system command that writes 'Hello World' to a file in /tmp, demonstrating command execution capability.

attacks.description: Retrieve information from the registry using the reg query command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will retrieve and display information from the specified registry key

attacks.description: Retrieve information from the registry using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will retrieve and display information from the specified registry key

attacks.description: Retrieve information from the registry using the reg query command without admin privileges
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will retrieve and display information from the specified registry key

attacks.description: Basic system/kernel information discovery
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays kernel version, hostname, and hardware architecture

attacks.description: Intermediate hardware information retrieval via DMI tables
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints detailed system manufacturer, model, and serial number from firmware

attacks.description: Advanced system reconnaissance combining hardware, CPU, and block device info
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists hardware components, CPU details, and storage devices in condensed format

attacks.description: Create a new service using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service will be created with the name TestService

attacks.description: Start a new process using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new command prompt will be opened

attacks.description: Modify an existing service using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService service will be set to start automatically

attacks.description: Adds a cron job to execute a benign command on every reboot
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a cron entry that touches a test file in /tmp during system startup. Requires root to modify /etc/crontab.

attacks.description: Creates and enables a systemd service to run a test command at boot
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a persistent systemd service that executes a harmless touch command. Service remains active across reboots.

attacks.description: Appends a test command to rc.local for execution during boot
attacks.expected_behavior: Modifies rc.local to create a test file at boot. Ensures file remains executable after modification.

attacks.description: Start the Telnet service to demonstrate application layer protocol usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Telnet service starts, allowing for potential C2 communication over the application layer protocol.

attacks.description: Create a web request to simulate C2 communication over HTTP.
attacks.expected_behavior: A web request is sent to the specified URL, simulating command and control communication.

attacks.description: Download a file using certutil to simulate data transfer over an application layer protocol.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt is downloaded from the specified URL and saved to the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Listen on port 8080 using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat will listen on port 8080 and wait for incoming connections

attacks.description: Send a request to port 8080 using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Curl will send a request to port 8080 and display the response

attacks.description: Establish a reverse shell using netcat
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat will establish a reverse shell and execute /bin/bash on the remote system

attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil to potentially obfuscate its contents.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an encoded version of a test file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to decode a Base64 string and write it to a file, demonstrating how obfuscated information can be decoded and executed.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a Base64 encoded string and writes the result to a file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Create a file with a benign payload and then hide it using the attrib command, demonstrating a basic form of file obfuscation through hiding.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in the temp directory, writes a benign string to it, and then hides the file.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a secret message' > secret.txt; base64 secret.txt > encoded_secret.txt
attacks.description: Creates a file with a secret message and then encodes it using base64
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates two files: one with the original message and another with the base64 encoded message

attacks.description: Creates a hexadecimal representation of the secret message file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file with the hexadecimal representation of the secret message

attacks.command: echo 'This is another secret message' > secret2.txt; gzip secret2.txt
attacks.description: Creates a file with another secret message and then compresses it using gzip
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed file with the secret message

attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil, which can be a step in preparing data for archiving or exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file testfile.txt will be encoded and saved as archived.txt in the TEMP directory.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to compress and archive a file, demonstrating the archiving of collected data.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file testfile.txt will be compressed and archived into a zip file named archived.zip in the TEMP directory, overwriting any existing file with the same name.

attacks.description: Use the makecab command to create a cabinet archive of a file, which is another method of archiving data on Windows.
attacks.expected_behavior: A cabinet archive named archived.cab will be created in the TEMP directory, containing the testfile.txt.

attacks.description: Basic command to create a tar archive of collected data
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive of the specified data

attacks.description: Intermediate command to create a tar archive and move it to a destination
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive of the specified data and moves it to the specified destination

attacks.command: tar -czf archive.tar.gz /path/to/data && chmod 600 archive.tar.gz && mv archive.tar.gz /path/to/destination
attacks.description: Advanced command to create a tar archive, change its permissions, and move it to a destination
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar archive of the specified data, changes its permissions, and moves it to the specified destination

attacks.command: schtasks /create /tn "Test Task" /tr "cmd /c echo Hello World! > %TEMP%\test.txt" /sc daily
attacks.description: Create a new scheduled task that runs a benign command
attacks.expected_behavior: A new scheduled task is created and runs daily, writing 'Hello World!' to a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: Delete a scheduled task
attacks.expected_behavior: The scheduled task 'Test Task' is deleted

attacks.description: Query all scheduled tasks
attacks.expected_behavior: A list of all scheduled tasks is displayed

attacks.description: Create user-level cron job to write to /tmp hourly
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a cron job in current user's crontab that appends 'test' to /tmp/log.txt every hour

attacks.description: Create system-wide cron job in /etc/cron.d
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a system cron job that writes 'hello' to /tmp/system_hello daily, requires root privileges

attacks.description: Append reboot-persistent cron job to user's crontab
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a cron job that creates /tmp/.startup at every system reboot using user's crontab

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Test > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Adds a new registry key to run a command at startup, writing to a temp file for testing.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory upon system startup, indicating the command was executed.

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Test > %TEMP%\test_admin.txt" /f
attacks.description: Adds a new registry key to run a command at startup, requiring admin privileges, writing to a temp file for testing.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named test_admin.txt will be created in the temp directory upon system startup, indicating the command was executed with admin privileges.

attacks.description: Deletes a previously added registry run key.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key and its associated startup command will be removed, preventing further execution at startup.

attacks.description: Appends a malicious command to the system's rc.local file for execution on startup
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed on the next system startup

attacks.description: Adds a cron job to execute a malicious command at regular intervals
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed at the specified interval

attacks.description: Enables a malicious service to start at user login
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious service will be started upon the next user login

attacks.command: powershell -Command "'Hello, this is a phishing test.' > %TEMP%\phishing_test.txt"
attacks.description: Create a file in the temp directory with a phishing test message
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named phishing_test.txt will be created in the %TEMP% directory with the specified message.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Content -Path %TEMP%\phishing_test.txt -Value 'This is a test of phishing activity.' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Append a line to the existing phishing test file
attacks.expected_behavior: The file phishing_test.txt will have an additional line appended to it.

attacks.description: Remove the phishing test file
attacks.expected_behavior: The file phishing_test.txt will be deleted from the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.command: bash -c "echo -n 'Please enter your password for verification: '; read -s password; echo '\\nPhishing simulation: Password captured.'"
attacks.description: Basic phishing simulation prompting for password input
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a password prompt and logs a simulation message after input

attacks.command:
bash -c "cat > /tmp/update.sh <<EOL
#!/bin/bash
echo 'System update required. Enter sudo password:'
read -s password
echo \"Simulated phishing: Password logged.\"
EOL
chmod +x /tmp/update.sh && echo 'Run /tmp/update.sh to proceed.'"
attacks.description: Intermediate fake update script creation
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a deceptive script in /tmp and instructs user to execute it

attacks.description: Advanced Base64-obfuscated credential prompt
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and executes a Base64-encoded username phishing prompt
